abstract: Since WikiLeaks threatened to “take down” a major American bank, Bank of America has been hunting for signs that its systems have been compromised.
snippet: Since WikiLeaks threatened to “take down” a major American bank, Bank of America has been hunting for signs that its systems have been compromised.
lead_paragraph: By the time the conference call ended, it was nearly midnight at Bank of America’s headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., but the bank’s counterespionage work was only just beginning.

headline.main: Facing Threat From WikiLeaks, Bank Plays Defense
headline.print_headline: Facing a New Type of Threat From WikiLeaks, a Bank Plays Defense

abstract: Since WikiLeaks threatened to “take down” a major American bank, officials at Bank of America have been hunting for any sign that its systems have been compromised.
snippet: Since WikiLeaks threatened to “take down” a major American bank, officials at Bank of America have been hunting for any sign that its systems have been compromised.
lead_paragraph: By the time the conference call ended, it was nearly midnight at Bank of America’s headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., but the bank’s counterespionage work was only just beginning, Nelson D. Schwartz reports in The New York Times.

headline.main: Facing WikiLeaks Threat, Bank Plays Defense

abstract: The bank agreed to pay more than $2.5 billion to resolve claims with Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae against Countrywide Financial.
snippet: The bank agreed to pay more than $2.5 billion to resolve claims with Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae against Countrywide Financial.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America announced on Monday that it had paid more than $2.5 billion to buy back troubled mortgages and resolve related claims from Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac  deals that may prompt a wave of such settlements by big banks.

headline.main: Bank of America Buys Back $2.5 Billion in Mortgage Debt
headline.print_headline: Bank of America Buys Back $2.5 Billion in Mortgage Debt

byline.original: By Ben Protess and Eric Dash

abstract: The bank announced on Monday that it would take a $2 billion charge stemming from an agreement with the two entities that centers on loans sold by Countrywide Financial.
snippet: The bank announced on Monday that it would take a $2 billion charge stemming from an agreement with the two entities that centers on loans sold by Countrywide Financial.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America announced on Monday that it would take a $2 billion charge to settle claims with Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae.

headline.main: Bank of America Settles Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Claims

abstract: The bank agreed to resolve claims with Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae against Countrywide Financial in a deal that may prompt a wave of settlements with other big lenders.
snippet: The bank agreed to resolve claims with Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae against Countrywide Financial in a deal that may prompt a wave of settlements with other big lenders.

headline.main: Bank of America Buys Back $2.5 Billion in Mortgage Debt

byline.original: By Ben Protess and Eric Dash
